threads.sub: what's the secret to a perfect carbonara?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This is the only way to make carbonara

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5aFrZQxBZWs&ab_channel=ChefDump

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18627771
People claiming that the original, as pictures, is just as creamy as the anglicized/americanized version are either being disingenuous or are too far removed from the common person to understand what it is they are talking about. Yes, the original version is delicious, very rich, very eggy, tastes amazing with pecorino and guanciale. But when someone wants something creamy, they don't want the light liquid coating as in OP's picture, they want a thick and viscous cream sauce.

That being said, it is possible to achieve that without cream, with just a slight technique variation from the traditional. Italians would usually have you remove the pan from the heat, and mix in the cold egg/cheese mixture or even remove it from the pan and mix it separately in a bowl with a small splash of water. This will yield the result in OP's picture which, again, is delicious, but not what those people want. For a thicker creamier sauce, keep the pan on the heat, but very low. Imagine you are making a very loose scrambled egg, except you don't want it to scramble. Keep stirring and stirring, don't let any of the sauce sit on the pan for too long, keep scraping. Keep adding more and more splashes of pasta water as needed if it gets too dry. Keep doing this for 3-4 minutes and you will have a genuinely thick and creamy sauce instead of a light coating, with just the original ingredients.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: The real secret is the amount of cheese. The cheese/egg mix for me is almost a paste as opposed to a runny mixture you see in most recipes. You then use pasta water to get it to the perfect consistency. Also, grating on a microplane makes a huge difference for whatever reason.

If you have a question about a specific recipe you are making or a specific product you saw in a youtube video it is okay to make your own thread, as long as you only post an image of said dish/product in the OP without anything that would otherwise promote the channel. It is fine to include a link to the video as long as you make it clear what it is a link to and why you are posting it. This applies to recipes you are making at home, or a specific tool or product you are interested in and might want more feedback on (e.g. a particular knife or blender). This DOES NOT include name brand food products such as a new flavor of chips or a new fast-food item.

If you start a new e-celeb general DO NOT post an image of anyone with an active youtube account or post a link to a specific video. This is intended for ALL youtube content and is not meant to promote any specific channel.

threads.com:
I tried making stew for the very first time and I forgot to roll the meat chunks in flour at the beginning. I've just realized this after it's been simmering for more than an hour and adding veggies.

Can I just add in a few shakes of flour into the stew now or is it too late?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18628004
yes you can n00b bro

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18628004
If you want to thicken the broth with flour, the best thing to do is to make a roux in a seperate pan. Equal parts fat (butter) and flour by volume, cook on low until it smells like fresh baked bread, then add it to your stew.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18628017
>then i would temper the roux with liquid
roux doesn't need to be tempered.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18628467
tempering the roux with liquid is just a way to make it easier to mix into the rest of the stew, not because it needs to be tempered. this allows you stir it in more gently.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18628004
as others have said, make a roux, brown it so the flour is plenty cooked, thin it out /slightly/ with some stock or water, and stir it into your stew.

alternatively, you don't necessarily need flour. you could just wait until the stew is sufficiently reduced that it is thickened by the fat and collagen from the meat.

The recipe from my last job:
>Two wonton wrappers
>Mozzarella
>5 slices of pepperoni

>Egg wash

>Fill one plate with water
>Wet wonton wrapper on one side
>Let excess water drip off then place on dry plate
>Lay base layer of mozzarella in center of wrapper
>Top with 5 pepperoni slices and 1 spoonful of marinara
>Add an additional layer of mozzarella then sprinkle with Pizza Dust
>Fold wrapper into open envelope shape (rectangle with bottom, right, and leg corners folded over and top corner undisturbed)
>Gently roll the bottom fold until wonton is sealed
>Take second wonton wrapper and follow steps 2 and 3
>Place filled wonton into center of empty wonton
>Fold left and right corners overtop filled wonton and pinch excess around filled wonton
>Take bottom corner and tuck over filled wonton
>Roll tightly, taking care to not tear the wrapper.
>Dip in egg wash
>Deep fry

I hated making this time consuming snack for children and drunkards. Imagine rolling 100 of these, it was a fucking nightmare.

McDonald’s hypes the everliving shit out of that sandwich, which God knows why, as it doesn’t seem to have that level of hype coming from anywhere else. There are as many people saying it’s disgusting as there are saying it’s good, if not more.

So I tried it, so that anons don’t have to, and I now know exactly where the lines are drawn, I think.. so, the McRib isn’t a bad sandwich. If made right ( pretty sure mine was ), it’s got a nice amount of flavor, the bun is sufficiently chewy and the pickles compliment the whole thing. It’s not great but, it’s not bad for fast food.

Here’s why it’s disgusting. It’s one of the only items that is truly postmodern. It is the thought of the McRib that makes it so disgusting to me. The meat is squished into the shape of a tiny rack of ribs, and something about that just feels off. It’s so poor an imitation, that it feels almost unnatural, like a tranny. There are things that the McRib can just never do.

And then the marketing is so brazen. They’re absolutely sure that by the end of the marketing campaign, that I will love the sandwich. It’s fucking disrespectful. No one is out here praising the McRib except for McDonald’s ( who has the marketing power of a small first world country ) and whatever soybois they have roped in, of which there are a depressing amount.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18628964__________________
Beef and Kale Stew
__________________


4 celery ribs, diced
3 large yellow onions, diced
6 kale heads chopped into spoon-size ribbons
1.5 lbs (680 grams) 80/20 ground beef, wadded tightly into approximately 1 oz lumps
2 lbs (907 grams) peeled and diced potatoes
(halved lengthwise >>> into half-inch planks >>> into half-inch dices)

4 packets (28 grams) unflavored gelatin
6 Tablespoons (85 grams) tomato paste (OPTIONAL)
1/8th cup (29 ml) apple cider vinegar
2 quarts (1,890 ml) distilled water
Entire head of garlic, minced
3 Tablespoons (21 grams) SRT+ Seasoning Blend (recipe below)
Salt

_____________________

In a large dutch oven, sautee onions in plenty of beef suet, lard or bacon fat until soft and slightly golden. Add kale in stages, constantly stirring, until it's all sweated down. Add distilled water and some salt.

Add all other ingredients EXCEPT minced garlic and seasoning blend.

Bring to a simmer then cover with heavy lid. Set burner to medium-low then let simmer for two hours.

Stir in garlic, seasoning blend and salt to taste. Simmer for one hour on medium low then serve.
______________________
______________________
SRT+ Herb & Spice Mix
(version 2.0)
_______________


1 oz_______sage (rubbed)
1 oz_______rosemary (cut)
1 oz_______thyme (whole)
1 oz_______dried basil
3 oz_______onion powder
3 oz_______garlic powder
________________________
20 grams___cayenne
20 grams___porcini mushroom powder
14 grams___black pepper
14 grams___fennel seed
7 grams____celery seed

Mix and grind in coffee/spice grinder until fully pulverized. Store in freezer to preserve potency.

_____________________
